speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: SCENE II. Alexandria. A room in the monument.

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Enter CLEOPATRA, CHARMIAN, and IRAS

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: My desolation does begin to make

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: A better life. 'Tis paltry to be Caesar;

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Not being Fortune, he's but Fortune's knave,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: A minister of her will: and it is great

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: To do that thing that ends all other deeds;

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Which shackles accidents and bolts up change;

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Which sleeps, and never palates more the dug,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: The beggar's nurse and Caesar's.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Enter, to the gates of the monument, PROCULEIUS, GALLUS and Soldiers

speaker: PROCULEIUS
text_entry: Caesar sends greeting to the Queen of Egypt;

speaker: PROCULEIUS
text_entry: And bids thee study on what fair demands

speaker: PROCULEIUS
text_entry: Thou mean'st to have him grant thee.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: What's thy name?

speaker: PROCULEIUS
text_entry: My name is Proculeius.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Antony

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Did tell me of you, bade me trust you; but

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: I do not greatly care to be deceived,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: That have no use for trusting. If your master

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Would have a queen his beggar, you must tell him,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: That majesty, to keep decorum, must

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: No less beg than a kingdom: if he please

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: To give me conquer'd Egypt for my son,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: He gives me so much of mine own, as I

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Will kneel to him with thanks.

speaker: PROCULEIUS
text_entry: Be of good cheer;

speaker: PROCULEIUS
text_entry: You're fall'n into a princely hand, fear nothing:

speaker: PROCULEIUS
text_entry: Make your full reference freely to my lord,

speaker: PROCULEIUS
text_entry: Who is so full of grace, that it flows over

speaker: PROCULEIUS
text_entry: On all that need: let me report to him

speaker: PROCULEIUS
text_entry: Your sweet dependency; and you shall find

speaker: PROCULEIUS
text_entry: A conqueror that will pray in aid for kindness,

speaker: PROCULEIUS
text_entry: Where he for grace is kneel'd to.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Pray you, tell him

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: I am his fortune's vassal, and I send him

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: The greatness he has got. I hourly learn

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: A doctrine of obedience; and would gladly

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Look him i' the face.

speaker: PROCULEIUS
text_entry: This I'll report, dear lady.

speaker: PROCULEIUS
text_entry: Have comfort, for I know your plight is pitied

speaker: PROCULEIUS
text_entry: Of him that caused it.

speaker: GALLUS
text_entry: You see how easily she may be surprised:

speaker: GALLUS
text_entry: Here PROCULEIUS and two of the Guard ascend the  monument by a ladder placed against a window, and,  having descended, come behind CLEOPATRA. Some of the Guard unbar and open the gates

speaker: GALLUS
text_entry: To PROCULEIUS and the Guard

speaker: GALLUS
text_entry: Guard her till Caesar come.

speaker: GALLUS
text_entry: Exit

speaker: IRAS
text_entry: Royal queen!

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: O Cleopatra! thou art taken, queen:

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Quick, quick, good hands.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Drawing a dagger

speaker: PROCULEIUS
text_entry: Hold, worthy lady, hold:

speaker: PROCULEIUS
text_entry: Seizes and disarms her

speaker: PROCULEIUS
text_entry: Do not yourself such wrong, who are in this

speaker: PROCULEIUS
text_entry: Relieved, but not betray'd.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: What, of death too,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: That rids our dogs of languish?

speaker: PROCULEIUS
text_entry: Cleopatra,

speaker: PROCULEIUS
text_entry: Do not abuse my master's bounty by

speaker: PROCULEIUS
text_entry: The undoing of yourself: let the world see

speaker: PROCULEIUS
text_entry: His nobleness well acted, which your death

speaker: PROCULEIUS
text_entry: Will never let come forth.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Where art thou, death?

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Come hither, come! come, come, and take a queen

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Worthy many babes and beggars!

speaker: PROCULEIUS
text_entry: O, temperance, lady!

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Sir, I will eat no meat, I'll not drink, sir;

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: If idle talk will once be necessary,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: I'll not sleep neither: this mortal house I'll ruin,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Do Caesar what he can. Know, sir, that I

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Will not wait pinion'd at your master's court;

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Nor once be chastised with the sober eye

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Of dull Octavia. Shall they hoist me up

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: And show me to the shouting varletry

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Of censuring Rome? Rather a ditch in Egypt

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Be gentle grave unto me! rather on Nilus' mud

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Lay me stark naked, and let the water-flies

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Blow me into abhorring! rather make

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: My country's high pyramides my gibbet,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: And hang me up in chains!

speaker: PROCULEIUS
text_entry: You do extend

speaker: PROCULEIUS
text_entry: These thoughts of horror further than you shall

speaker: PROCULEIUS
text_entry: Find cause in Caesar.

speaker: PROCULEIUS
text_entry: Enter DOLABELLA

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: Proculeius,

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: What thou hast done thy master Caesar knows,

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: And he hath sent for thee: for the queen,

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: I'll take her to my guard.

speaker: PROCULEIUS
text_entry: So, Dolabella,

speaker: PROCULEIUS
text_entry: It shall content me best: be gentle to her.

speaker: PROCULEIUS
text_entry: To CLEOPATRA

speaker: PROCULEIUS
text_entry: To Caesar I will speak what you shall please,

speaker: PROCULEIUS
text_entry: If you'll employ me to him.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Say, I would die.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Exeunt PROCULEIUS and Soldiers

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: Most noble empress, you have heard of me?

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: I cannot tell.

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: Assuredly you know me.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: No matter, sir, what I have heard or known.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: You laugh when boys or women tell their dreams;

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Is't not your trick?

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: I understand not, madam.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: I dream'd there was an Emperor Antony:

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: O, such another sleep, that I might see

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: But such another man!

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: If it might please ye,--

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: His face was as the heavens; and therein stuck

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: A sun and moon, which kept their course,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: and lighted

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: The little O, the earth.

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: Most sovereign creature,--

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: His legs bestrid the ocean: his rear'd arm

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Crested the world: his voice was propertied

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: As all the tuned spheres, and that to friends;

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: But when he meant to quail and shake the orb,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: He was as rattling thunder. For his bounty,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: There was no winter in't; an autumn 'twas

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: That grew the more by reaping: his delights

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Were dolphin-like; they show'd his back above

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: The element they lived in: in his livery

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Walk'd crowns and crownets; realms and islands were

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: As plates dropp'd from his pocket.

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: Cleopatra!

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Think you there was, or might be, such a man

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: As this I dream'd of?

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: Gentle madam, no.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: You lie, up to the hearing of the gods.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: But, if there be, or ever were, one such,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: It's past the size of dreaming: nature wants stuff

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: To vie strange forms with fancy; yet, to imagine

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: And Antony, were nature's piece 'gainst fancy,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Condemning shadows quite.

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: Hear me, good madam.

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: Your loss is as yourself, great; and you bear it

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: As answering to the weight: would I might never

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: O'ertake pursued success, but I do feel,

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: By the rebound of yours, a grief that smites

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: My very heart at root.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: I thank you, sir,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Know you what Caesar means to do with me?

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: I am loath to tell you what I would you knew.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Nay, pray you, sir,--

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: Though he be honourable,--

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: He'll lead me, then, in triumph?

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: Madam, he will; I know't.

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: Flourish, and shout within, 'Make way there: Octavius Caesar!'

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: Enter OCTAVIUS CAESAR, GALLUS, PROCULEIUS, MECAENAS, SELEUCUS, and others of his Train

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Which is the Queen of Egypt?

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: It is the emperor, madam.

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: CLEOPATRA kneels

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Arise, you shall not kneel:

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: I pray you, rise; rise, Egypt.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Sir, the gods

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Will have it thus; my master and my lord

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: I must obey.

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Take to you no hard thoughts:

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: The record of what injuries you did us,

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Though written in our flesh, we shall remember

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: As things but done by chance.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Sole sir o' the world,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: I cannot project mine own cause so well

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: To make it clear; but do confess I have

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Been laden with like frailties which before

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Have often shamed our sex.

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Cleopatra, know,

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: We will extenuate rather than enforce:

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: If you apply yourself to our intents,

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Which towards you are most gentle, you shall find

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: A benefit in this change; but if you seek

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: To lay on me a cruelty, by taking

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Antony's course, you shall bereave yourself

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Of my good purposes, and put your children

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: To that destruction which I'll guard them from,

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: If thereon you rely. I'll take my leave.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: And may, through all the world: 'tis yours; and we,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Your scutcheons and your signs of conquest, shall

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Hang in what place you please. Here, my good lord.

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: You shall advise me in all for Cleopatra.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: This is the brief of money, plate, and jewels,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: I am possess'd of: 'tis exactly valued;

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Not petty things admitted. Where's Seleucus?

speaker: SELEUCUS
text_entry: Here, madam.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: This is my treasurer: let him speak, my lord,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Upon his peril, that I have reserved

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: To myself nothing. Speak the truth, Seleucus.

speaker: SELEUCUS
text_entry: Madam,

speaker: SELEUCUS
text_entry: I had rather seal my lips, than, to my peril,

speaker: SELEUCUS
text_entry: Speak that which is not.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: What have I kept back?

speaker: SELEUCUS
text_entry: Enough to purchase what you have made known.

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Nay, blush not, Cleopatra; I approve

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Your wisdom in the deed.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: See, Caesar! O, behold,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: How pomp is follow'd! mine will now be yours;

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: And, should we shift estates, yours would be mine.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: The ingratitude of this Seleucus does

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Even make me wild: O slave, of no more trust

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Than love that's hired! What, goest thou back? thou shalt

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Go back, I warrant thee; but I'll catch thine eyes,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Though they had wings: slave, soulless villain, dog!

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: O rarely base!

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Good queen, let us entreat you.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: O Caesar, what a wounding shame is this,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: That thou, vouchsafing here to visit me,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Doing the honour of thy lordliness

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: To one so meek, that mine own servant should

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Parcel the sum of my disgraces by

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Addition of his envy! Say, good Caesar,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: That I some lady trifles have reserved,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Immoment toys, things of such dignity

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: As we greet modern friends withal; and say,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Some nobler token I have kept apart

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: For Livia and Octavia, to induce

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Their mediation; must I be unfolded

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: With one that I have bred? The gods! it smites me

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Beneath the fall I have.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: To SELEUCUS

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Prithee, go hence;

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Or I shall show the cinders of my spirits

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Through the ashes of my chance: wert thou a man,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Thou wouldst have mercy on me.

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Forbear, Seleucus.

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Exit SELEUCUS

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Be it known, that we, the greatest, are misthought

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: For things that others do; and, when we fall,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: We answer others' merits in our name,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Are therefore to be pitied.

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Cleopatra,

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Not what you have reserved, nor what acknowledged,

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Put we i' the roll of conquest: still be't yours,

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Bestow it at your pleasure; and believe,

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Caesar's no merchant, to make prize with you

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Of things that merchants sold. Therefore be cheer'd;

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Make not your thoughts your prisons: no, dear queen;

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: For we intend so to dispose you as

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Yourself shall give us counsel. Feed, and sleep:

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Our care and pity is so much upon you,

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: That we remain your friend; and so, adieu.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: My master, and my lord!

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Not so. Adieu.

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Flourish. Exeunt OCTAVIUS CAESAR and his train

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: He words me, girls, he words me, that I should not

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Be noble to myself: but, hark thee, Charmian.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Whispers CHARMIAN

speaker: IRAS
text_entry: Finish, good lady; the bright day is done,

speaker: IRAS
text_entry: And we are for the dark.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Hie thee again:

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: I have spoke already, and it is provided;

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Go put it to the haste.

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: Madam, I will.

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: Re-enter DOLABELLA

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: Where is the queen?

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: Behold, sir.

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: Exit

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Dolabella!

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: Madam, as thereto sworn by your command,

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: Which my love makes religion to obey,

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: I tell you this: Caesar through Syria

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: Intends his journey; and within three days

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: You with your children will he send before:

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: Make your best use of this: I have perform'd

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: Your pleasure and my promise.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Dolabella,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: I shall remain your debtor.

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: I your servant,

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: Adieu, good queen; I must attend on Caesar.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Farewell, and thanks.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Exit DOLABELLA

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Now, Iras, what think'st thou?

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Thou, an Egyptian puppet, shalt be shown

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: In Rome, as well as I mechanic slaves

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: With greasy aprons, rules, and hammers, shall

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Uplift us to the view; in their thick breaths,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Rank of gross diet, shall be enclouded,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: And forced to drink their vapour.

speaker: IRAS
text_entry: The gods forbid!

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Nay, 'tis most certain, Iras: saucy lictors

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Will catch at us, like strumpets; and scald rhymers

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Ballad us out o' tune: the quick comedians

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Extemporally will stage us, and present

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Our Alexandrian revels; Antony

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Shall be brought drunken forth, and I shall see

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Some squeaking Cleopatra boy my greatness

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: I' the posture of a whore.

speaker: IRAS
text_entry: O the good gods!

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Nay, that's certain.

speaker: IRAS
text_entry: I'll never see 't; for, I am sure, my nails

speaker: IRAS
text_entry: Are stronger than mine eyes.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Why, that's the way

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: To fool their preparation, and to conquer

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Their most absurd intents.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Re-enter CHARMIAN

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Now, Charmian!

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Show me, my women, like a queen: go fetch

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: My best attires: I am again for Cydnus,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: To meet Mark Antony: sirrah Iras, go.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Now, noble Charmian, we'll dispatch indeed;

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: And, when thou hast done this chare, I'll give thee leave

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: To play till doomsday. Bring our crown and all.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Wherefore's this noise?

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Exit IRAS. A noise within

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Enter a Guardsman

speaker: Guard
text_entry: Here is a rural fellow

speaker: Guard
text_entry: That will not be denied your highness presence:

speaker: Guard
text_entry: He brings you figs.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Let him come in.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Exit Guardsman

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: What poor an instrument

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: May do a noble deed! he brings me liberty.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: My resolution's placed, and I have nothing

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Of woman in me: now from head to foot

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: I am marble-constant; now the fleeting moon

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: No planet is of mine.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Re-enter Guardsman, with Clown bringing in a basket

speaker: Guard
text_entry: This is the man.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Avoid, and leave him.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Exit Guardsman

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Hast thou the pretty worm of Nilus there,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: That kills and pains not?

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Truly, I have him: but I would not be the party

speaker: Clown
text_entry: that should desire you to touch him, for his biting

speaker: Clown
text_entry: is immortal; those that do die of it do seldom or

speaker: Clown
text_entry: never recover.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Rememberest thou any that have died on't?

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Very many, men and women too. I heard of one of

speaker: Clown
text_entry: them no longer than yesterday: a very honest woman,

speaker: Clown
text_entry: but something given to lie; as a woman should not

speaker: Clown
text_entry: do, but in the way of honesty: how she died of the

speaker: Clown
text_entry: biting of it, what pain she felt: truly, she makes

speaker: Clown
text_entry: a very good report o' the worm; but he that will

speaker: Clown
text_entry: believe all that they say, shall never be saved by

speaker: Clown
text_entry: half that they do: but this is most fallible, the

speaker: Clown
text_entry: worm's an odd worm.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Get thee hence; farewell.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: I wish you all joy of the worm.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Setting down his basket

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Farewell.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: You must think this, look you, that the worm will

speaker: Clown
text_entry: do his kind.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Ay, ay; farewell.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Look you, the worm is not to be trusted but in the

speaker: Clown
text_entry: keeping of wise people; for, indeed, there is no

speaker: Clown
text_entry: goodness in worm.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Take thou no care; it shall be heeded.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Very good. Give it nothing, I pray you, for it is

speaker: Clown
text_entry: not worth the feeding.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Will it eat me?

speaker: Clown
text_entry: You must not think I am so simple but I know the

speaker: Clown
text_entry: devil himself will not eat a woman: I know that a

speaker: Clown
text_entry: woman is a dish for the gods, if the devil dress her

speaker: Clown
text_entry: not. But, truly, these same whoreson devils do the

speaker: Clown
text_entry: gods great harm in their women; for in every ten

speaker: Clown
text_entry: that they make, the devils mar five.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Well, get thee gone; farewell.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Yes, forsooth: I wish you joy o' the worm.

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Exit

speaker: Clown
text_entry: Re-enter IRAS with a robe, crown,  and c

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Give me my robe, put on my crown; I have

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Immortal longings in me: now no more

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: The juice of Egypt's grape shall moist this lip:

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Yare, yare, good Iras; quick. Methinks I hear

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Antony call; I see him rouse himself

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: To praise my noble act; I hear him mock

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: The luck of Caesar, which the gods give men

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: To excuse their after wrath: husband, I come:

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Now to that name my courage prove my title!

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: I am fire and air; my other elements

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: I give to baser life. So; have you done?

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Come then, and take the last warmth of my lips.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Farewell, kind Charmian; Iras, long farewell.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Kisses them. IRAS falls and dies

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Have I the aspic in my lips? Dost fall?

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: If thou and nature can so gently part,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: The stroke of death is as a lover's pinch,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Which hurts, and is desired. Dost thou lie still?

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: If thus thou vanishest, thou tell'st the world

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: It is not worth leave-taking.

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: Dissolve, thick cloud, and rain; that I may say,

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: The gods themselves do weep!

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: This proves me base:

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: If she first meet the curled Antony,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: He'll make demand of her, and spend that kiss

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Which is my heaven to have. Come, thou

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: mortal wretch,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: To an asp, which she applies to her breast

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: With thy sharp teeth this knot intrinsicate

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Of life at once untie: poor venomous fool

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Be angry, and dispatch. O, couldst thou speak,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: That I might hear thee call great Caesar ass

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Unpolicied!

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: O eastern star!

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Peace, peace!

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Dost thou not see my baby at my breast,

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: That sucks the nurse asleep?

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: O, break! O, break!

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: As sweet as balm, as soft as air, as gentle,--

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: O Antony!--Nay, I will take thee too.

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Applying another asp to her arm

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: What should I stay--

speaker: CLEOPATRA
text_entry: Dies

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: In this vile world? So, fare thee well.

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: Now boast thee, death, in thy possession lies

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: A lass unparallel'd. Downy windows, close;

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: And golden Phoebus never be beheld

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: Of eyes again so royal! Your crown's awry;

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: I'll mend it, and then play.

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: Enter the Guard, rushing in

speaker: First Guard
text_entry: Where is the queen?

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: Speak softly, wake her not.

speaker: First Guard
text_entry: Caesar hath sent--

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: Too slow a messenger.

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: Applies an asp

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: O, come apace, dispatch! I partly feel thee.

speaker: First Guard
text_entry: Approach, ho! All's not well: Caesar's beguiled.

speaker: Second Guard
text_entry: There's Dolabella sent from Caesar; call him.

speaker: First Guard
text_entry: What work is here! Charmian, is this well done?

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: It is well done, and fitting for a princess

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: Descended of so many royal kings.

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: Ah, soldier!

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: Dies

speaker: CHARMIAN
text_entry: Re-enter DOLABELLA

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: How goes it here?

speaker: Second Guard
text_entry: All dead.

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: Caesar, thy thoughts

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: Touch their effects in this: thyself art coming

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: To see perform'd the dreaded act which thou

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: So sought'st to hinder.

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: Within  'A way there, a way for Caesar!'

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: Re-enter OCTAVIUS CAESAR and all his train marching

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: O sir, you are too sure an augurer;

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: That you did fear is done.

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Bravest at the last,

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: She levell'd at our purposes, and, being royal,

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Took her own way. The manner of their deaths?

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: I do not see them bleed.

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: Who was last with them?

speaker: First Guard
text_entry: A simple countryman, that brought her figs:

speaker: First Guard
text_entry: This was his basket.

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Poison'd, then.

speaker: First Guard
text_entry: O Caesar,

speaker: First Guard
text_entry: This Charmian lived but now; she stood and spake:

speaker: First Guard
text_entry: I found her trimming up the diadem

speaker: First Guard
text_entry: On her dead mistress; tremblingly she stood

speaker: First Guard
text_entry: And on the sudden dropp'd.

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: O noble weakness!

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: If they had swallow'd poison, 'twould appear

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: By external swelling: but she looks like sleep,

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: As she would catch another Antony

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: In her strong toil of grace.

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: Here, on her breast,

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: There is a vent of blood and something blown:

speaker: DOLABELLA
text_entry: The like is on her arm.

speaker: First Guard
text_entry: This is an aspic's trail: and these fig-leaves

speaker: First Guard
text_entry: Have slime upon them, such as the aspic leaves

speaker: First Guard
text_entry: Upon the caves of Nile.

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Most probable

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: That so she died; for her physician tells me

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: She hath pursued conclusions infinite

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Of easy ways to die. Take up her bed;

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: And bear her women from the monument:

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: She shall be buried by her Antony:

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: No grave upon the earth shall clip in it

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: A pair so famous. High events as these

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Strike those that make them; and their story is

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: No less in pity than his glory which

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Brought them to be lamented. Our army shall

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: In solemn show attend this funeral;

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: And then to Rome. Come, Dolabella, see

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: High order in this great solemnity.

speaker: OCTAVIUS CAESAR
text_entry: Exeunt
